Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Sea-level and paleoclimate reconstructions from Mallorca Cave Deposits
Award.AbstractNarration:
The potential impacts of climate induced sea level rise on coastal societies are a pressing global issue. The best way to understand sea level responses to climate change is to observe how the processes have proceeded in the past. This research aims to produce and combine high-resolution climate and sea level records so that an interpretation of how the sea level response to climate variation has operated during Late Pleistocene time. The two records will produce direct information on how sea level rose and fell in response to the growth and decay of the major northern hemisphere ice sheets in the Mediterranean. Under the supervision of Dr. Chuan-Chou Shen, this project will be conducted at the National University of Taiwan. Dr. Shen is responsible for the refined analytical precision of mass spectrometric dating methods that will allow for radiometric ages with minimal error.

Carbonate encrustations (CE) are documented above, below, and at the current Mediterranean sea level and stalagmites from the same caves can be accurately dated using U-series methodology, thus precisely constraining the elevation of each sea-level stand and a climate history for the region. Speleothems are sensitive to climate changes as their growth mechanism is linked to Earth's atmosphere and hydrosphere. Oxygen and carbon isotopic variations along the growth axis of a given speleothem deposited under isotopic equilibrium conditions are potentially powerful tracers of climatic changes. Dating of fifteen CE and two stalagmites previously collected from Mallorca by means of Multi Collector-Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometer will be used to generate ages. The high resolution U/Th chronology of the two stalagmites and the precisely dated CE will provide timelines for past sea level high and low stands and climate variability. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Science Council of Taiwan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Climate change influenced eustatic sea level rise is a prominent issue communities around the globe are currently facing. With the potential to cause significant damage to coastal societies, it is crucial that we develop a better understanding of how climate can affect mean sea level and to what degree sea level can fluctuate in response to climate change. Caves along the Mallorcan coast are partially flooded with water that approximates mean sea level of the Mediterranean Sea (Fig. 1). Calcium carbonate encrustations (Phreatic Overgrowths on Speleothems: POS) precipitate out of the seawater and encrust onto to the walls and speleothems within the cave (Ginés et al., 2012). Therefore by dating POS above and below the current elevation of sea level, a record of past sea level high stands and low stands can be produced (Dorale et al., 2010). In addition, stable isotopes within precisely dated calcium carbonate stalagmites were use to reconstruct the past climate of the western Mediterranean during periods of sea level variation. Oxygen isotopes that eventually become incorporated into the mineral structure of stalagmites fractionate in accordance with climate (Fairfield et al., 2006). By performing isotope analysis it becomes possible to reconstruct climate. This project sought to add to the historical record of sea level and climate in the western Mediterranean through dating of POS and stalagmites in coastal Mallorcan caves.

POS and stalagmites were dated through uranium series methods at the HiSpec Clean Lab run by Professor Chuan-Chou Shen at the National Taiwan University (NTU). This process involved sampling of calcium carbonate, preparation via chemistry and processing using a multi collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer. The resulting age of the oldest POS indicates that a sea level high stand of 4.9 m above present sea level (apsl) occurred at 474,921 ± 197,096 years. Four additional dates also show that there was significant sea level fluctuation between 180,000 and 115,000 years (Fig. 2). Initially during this time interval a sea level high stand (1.5 m apsl) was present at 170,479 ± 2,771 years. A POS sample obtained from 12 meters below present sea level indicates that after this high stand sea level dropped dramatically at 156,313 ± 1,898 years.  A sea level low stand such as this represents the timing of a past glacial maximum when ice sheets were larger and less water was concentrated in the oceans (Lambeck et al., 2002). Following this low stand there was a rapid sea level rise to high stands at 120,663 ± 1,501 (2 m apsl) and 118,053 ± 941 years (3 m apsl).

From the three stalagmites (Drac, Artà and Vallgonera), 23 powdered samples were obtained and dated for paleoclimate work. Out of these samples, 19 were used to produce a high-resolution time series for the Drac stalagmite that grew between 229,387 ± 2,515 and 47,998 ± 134 years. Although the calculated ages from the lower 175 mm of this sample resulted in ages that had significant error, the upper 20 mm (108,688 ± 484 - 47,998 ± 134 years) grew during the recognized sea level variation from the dated POS. In addition, an initial youngest age for the Artà stalagmite (102,076 ± 389 years) suggests that the entire interval may overlap with the growth period of both stalagmites. Unfortunately, due to a sensor malfunction with the mass spectrometer more dates were unable to be produced during the EAPSI program. These remaining dates will be processed with the help of Professor Shen’s lab. Since sampling resolution for isotope analysis cannot be determined until all dates are processed, this will be done following the processing of the ages.
